     public sealed class ArrayData
     {
         public readonly IArrowType DataType;

 Review comment:
   I think these can remain `readonly` can't they?
   
   I'd be surprised if someone changed the Length of an array instance.

pgovind commented on pull request #3806: ARROW-4719: [C#] Implement ChunkedArray, Column and Table in C#
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3806#discussion_r262301613
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/ArrayData.cs
 ##########
 @@ -22,9 +22,9 @@ namespace Apache.Arrow
     public sealed class ArrayData
     {
         public readonly IArrowType DataType;
-        public readonly int Length;
 
 Review comment:
   Array.Slice is manipulating it. The way I look at it, ArrayData is just a view over the same underlying buffers, so if someone wants a slice, "Length" needs to change. We could still keep it readonly and provide a set method(which is what I started out with originally), but I thought this was more succinct.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

pgovind commented on pull request #3806: ARROW-4719: [C#] Implement ChunkedArray, Column and Table in C#
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3806#discussion_r262301613
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/ArrayData.cs
 ##########
 @@ -22,9 +22,9 @@ namespace Apache.Arrow
     public sealed class ArrayData
     {
         public readonly IArrowType DataType;
-        public readonly int Length;
 
 Review comment:
   Array.Slice is manipulating it. The way I look at it, ArrayData is just a view over the same underlying buffers, so if someone wants a slice, "Length" needs to change. We could still keep it readonly and provide a new ctor(which is what I started out with originally), but I thought this was more succinct.

+    /// <summary>
+    /// A Column data structure that logically represents a column in a dataset

+    {
+        public readonly Field Field;
 
 Review comment:
   This should be a property instead. In general, classes shouldn't directly expose fields publicly, but instead expose them through properties.

+﻿// Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one or more
+// contributor license agreements. See the NOTICE file distributed with
+// this work for additional information regarding copyright ownership.
+// The ASF licenses this file to You under the Apache License, Version 2.0
+// (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with

+// distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+// WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+// See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+// limitations under the License.
+
+using System;
+using System.Collections.Generic;
+using Apache.Arrow;
+using Apache.Arrow.Types;
+
+namespace Apache.Arrow
+{
+    /// <summary>
+    /// A data structure to manage a list of primitive Array arrays logically as one large array
+    /// </summary>
+    internal class ChunkedArray
+    {
+        public readonly IList<Array> Arrays;
+        public readonly IArrowType DataType;
+        public readonly long Length;
+        public readonly long NullCount;
+
+        public ChunkedArray(IList<Array> arrays)
+        {
+            Arrays = arrays ?? throw new ArgumentNullException(nameof(arrays));
+            if (arrays.Count < 1)
+            {
+                throw new ArgumentException($"Count must be atleast 1. Got {arrays.Count} instead");
 
 Review comment:
   type-o `atleast`
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

eerhardt commented on pull request #3806: ARROW-4719: [C#] Implement ChunkedArray, Column and Table in C#
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3806#discussion_r272242472
 
 

 ##########
 File path: csharp/src/Apache.Arrow/Arrays/Array.cs
 ##########
 @@ -59,5 +59,22 @@ internal static void Accept<T>(T array, IArrowArrayVisitor visitor)
                     break;
             }
         }
+
+        public Array Slice(int offset, int length)
+        {
+            if (offset > Length)
+            {
+                throw new ArgumentException($"Offset {offset} cannot be greater than Length {Length} for Array.Slice");
+            }
+
+            length = Math.Min(Data.Length - offset, length);
 
 Review comment:
   Throwing an ArgumentOutOfRangeException is how `Span<T>` works in .NET (and honestly any other API I've seen in the BCL). If a caller passes in a value that is too large, it is typically a mistake, and we should tell them.
   
   ---
   In reply to: [262338881](https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3806#discussion_r262338881) [](ancestors = 262338881)

fields.description: Implement "ChunkedArray", "Column" and "Table" in arrow/csharp. They are useful types to represent pieces in a dataset
